The Act may be cited as the "Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009". It includes a provision for the temporary refundability of the solar energy credit. The Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009 includes a provision for the temporary refundability of the residential solar energy credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This allows taxpayers to increase their aggregate credits for expenditures made during the taxable year without certain limitations. The Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009 allows for the temporary refundability of the residential solar energy credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This provision enables taxpayers to increase their credits for expenditures made during the taxable year without limitations. Additionally, there are special rules for solar energy credits, with separate application of sections 38 and 39 for such credits. The Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009 allows for the temporary refundability of the residential solar energy credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Special rules apply to solar energy credits, with excess credits treated as a credit under subpart C. The Solar Stimulus for Job Creation and Energy Independence Act of 2009 allows for the temporary refundability of the residential solar energy credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Special rules apply to solar energy credits, with excess credits treated as a credit under subpart C. The term 'solar energy credits' refers to the energy credit attributable to specific property described in the Code. This provision does not apply after December 31, 2010, and there are conforming amendments to include solar energy credits in specified credits sections of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act, specifically relating to the insertion of solar energy credits in specified sections of the Internal Revenue Code. TEMPORARY REFUNDABILITY OF DEPRECIATION DEDUCTION FOR SOLAR ENERGY PROPERTY. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a 33\1/3\ percent energy credit for certain property deductions until January 1, 2011. Additionally, depreciation is denied where the credit is elected. The amendment denies depreciation deductions if the taxpayer elects the energy credit for specific property. A conforming amendment is made to section 48(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Exception from private activity bond tests for financing of solar energy property. The amendment exempts solar energy property from private business use and loan financing tests under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to obligations issued after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Exception from subsidized energy financing rules for solar energy property. Amends the definition of subsidized energy financing in the Internal Revenue Code to exclude certain loans. Effective for property placed in service after a specified date in taxable years ending after that date. 

SEC. 6. Refundable investment credit for property used to manufacture solar energy property. SEC. 7. Government procurement of solar energy. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include property used to manufacture equipment for solar energy in the definition of energy property. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Amends Section 203 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to allow contracts for renewable energy for up to 25 years, bypassing certain restrictions in the United States Code.
